TEXT:
Chief Complaint: Unresponsive, respiratory failure, meningitis
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /
   her note above, including assessment and plan.
   HPI:
   53yoF with history of remote gastric bypass; presented with one day of
   nausea/emesis progressing to unresponsiveness.  She was intubated at
   [**Location (un) 9927**] Hospital; head CT with diffuse cerebral edema, febrile
   to 104; given vancomycin/ceftriaxone/acyclovir and transferred to [**Hospital1 1**]
   ED.  She had difficulty oxygenating and evidence of ARDS
   radiographically, because of hypoxemia her PEEP was increased to 20 and
   she subsequently developed hypotension.  Initiated on pressors.  Neuro
   consult obtained recommending LP, however with concern for possible
   herniation LP was not performed.
   24 Hour Events:
   She received aggressive fluid resucitation with improvement in her BP
   (now off pressors) and improvement in lactate.  She was continued on
   her broad antibiotics with addition of oseltamivir and ampicillin.  She
   was placed on ARDSnet ventilation.  Arterial line was placed.  Urine
   output approximately 100ml/hr.
   History obtained from Medical records
   Patient unable to provide history: Sedated

   53yoF with fever, altered mental status; likely meningoencephalitis,
   sepsis, ARDS.
   1.  Meningoencephalitis:   Unclear source, and difficulty obtaining
   sample because of inability to perform LP.
   - covered broadly with
   vancomycin/ceftriaxone/ampicillin/oseltamivir/acyclovir.
   - Neuro to follow and discuss safety of LP as well as management of her
   cerebral edema.
   - Will discuss with neuro regarding possible ICP monitoring, possible
   neurosurgery consult.
   - await viral studies, cultures, etc.
   - replace central line
   2.  Hypoxemic respiratory failure from ARDS, suspect due to septic
   shock versus aspiration.  Ppl 31, Vt 7ml/kg, Rate 30; PEEP 18, FiO2 0.8
   - Limited ability to allow permissive hypercapnea in setting of
   cerebral edema.  Will follow ABG, consider decrease in Vt to 5 or
   6ml/kg if will tolerate from a CNS standpoint.
   - measure Ideal body weight
   - Esophageal balloon given borderline Ppl; PEEP titration
   3.       CV:  likely sepsis-myocardial dysfunction versus demand
   ischemia
   - will follow markers, EKG
   - TTE
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2109-12-18**] 11:58 PM
 replace central line

   Stress ulcer:  Famotidine
   VAP:  HOB, mouthcare/chlorhexidine
   Communication:  Will update family today, ICU consent signed
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition : Critically ill, remain in ICU
   Total time spent:  45minutes CCT
Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of gastric bypass who presented with nausea and vomiting that progressed to unresponsiveness.
- She was intubated at another hospital due to respiratory failure and diagnosed with diffuse cerebral edema, febrile to 104 degrees Fahrenheit.
- The patient was given broad-spectrum antibiotics (vancomycin, ceftriaxone, acyclovir) and transferred to the current hospital.
- She developed hypotension and difficulty oxygenating, leading to the diagnosis of ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome).
- The patient's condition improved with aggressive fluid resuscitation, and she was placed on ARDSnet ventilation.
- She is currently off pressors, with stable vital signs, and has improved urine output.
- The patient remains critically ill with suspected meningoencephalitis, sepsis, and ARDS.
- She is on broad-spectrum antibiotics, including coverage for influenza and meningitis pathogens.
- Neurology consultation is pending to discuss the safety of performing a lumbar puncture (LP) and management of cerebral edema.
- The patient's blood cultures are pending, and she is awaiting further diagnostic tests.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Meningoencephalitis: The patient's altered mental status, fever, and possible inability to perform LP indicate a potential central nervous system infection. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been initiated, but the source of infection is

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of gastric bypass who presented with nausea and vomiting, progressing to unresponsiveness. She was intubated and diagnosed with diffuse cerebral edema, fever, and meningitis. The patient is currently in the ICU for critical care.

The patient's medical history includes a remote gastric bypass procedure. She presented with one day of nausea and emesis, progressing to unresponsiveness. She was intubated at [**Location (un)**] Hospital and transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] ED due to febrile status of 104 degrees Fahrenheit. She received vancomycin, ceftriaxone, and acyclovir. The patient developed difficulty oxygenating and evidence of ARDS radiographically, leading to an increase in PEEP to 20. Subsequently, she developed hypotension and required initiation of pressors. Neuro consult recommended LP but was concerned about possible herniation, so LP was not performed.

The patient received aggressive fluid resuscitation with improvement in her blood pressure (now off pressors) and improvement in lactate. She continues on broad antibiotics, including oseltamivir and ampicillin. The patient is being ventilated using ARDSnet ventilation. An arterial line was placed, and her urine output is approximately 100 mL/hr.

The patient is unable to provide a medical history as she is sedated. There are no known drug allergies. The last doses of

- 53-year-old female with a history of gastric bypass presented with nausea and emesis, progressing to unresponsiveness.
- She was intubated and diagnosed with diffuse cerebral edema, febrile to 104 degrees Fahrenheit.
- She received vancomycin, ceftriaxone, acyclovir, and was transferred to another hospital.
- Upon arrival, she had difficulty oxygenating and evidence of ARDS radiographically.
- Her PEEP was increased to 20, leading to hypotension, and she was placed on pressors.
- Neuro consult recommended LP, but due to concern for possible herniation, it was not performed.
- She received aggressive fluid resuscitation with improvement in her blood pressure and lactate levels.
- She was continued on broad antibiotics, including oseltamivir and ampicillin, and placed on ARDSnet ventilation.
- She has a urinary catheter, arterial line, and endotracheal tube in place.
- Her current vital signs include a temperature of 38.1 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 124 beats per minute, blood pressure of 124/82 mmHg, respiratory rate of 31 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%.
- She has been sedated and unable to provide a medical history.
- Her last doses of antibiotics were given at different times.

TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
 ESOPHOGEAL BALLOON - At [**2109-12-19**] 10:18 AM
 LUMBAR PUNCTURE - At [**2109-12-19**] 12:05 PM
 LUMBAR PUNCTURE - At [**2109-12-19**] 02:00 PM done in IR
 MULTI LUMEN - START [**2109-12-19**] 05:20 PM
 MULTI LUMEN - STOP [**2109-12-19**] 06:46 PM
 ARTERIAL LINE - START [**2109-12-19**] 08:37 PM
 ARTERIAL LINE - STOP [**2109-12-20**] 04:00 AM
 ARTERIAL LINE - START [**2109-12-20**] 04:31 AM
   Neuro attempted LP and failed, LP under fluoro with 7000 WBCs, 1000RBCS
   protein 645, glucose 34. Likely bacterial meningitis.
   Opening pressure 37, bolt placed by NS with initial ICP 25. Given
   mannitol and hypertonic saline with improvement to 13. q6 serum osms
   and sodium. Goal ICP<20, CPP>55, OSM>300 but <320, sodium around 150.
   Increased TV to 430 with goal of slight alkalosis.
   Curbside ID says no steroids, increased abx doses, full consult in am.
   Esophageal balloon placed. Weened FiO2 to 50% but didn't adjust PEEP as
   esophageal balloon indicated negative transpleural pressures.
   CEZ trending down, ordered TTE but unable to be done due to logisitics.
   At CT to r/o hematoma from bolt, catheter came out and needed
   replacement by NS.
   Patient unable to provide history: Sedated
   Allergies:

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension who presented with fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. The patient's condition suggests multiple medical complications that require urgent attention. 

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a Ventilator mode of CMV/AutoFlow, set tidal volume (Vt) of 430 mL, respiratory rate (RR) of 30 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 18 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. The RSBI deferred due to elevated ICP, PEEP > 10, and hemodynamic instability. The ABG results indicate a pH of 7.46, PaCO2 of 26 mmHg, PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 355, and Ve of 12.9 L/min. These findings suggest adequate oxygenation but may require further adjustments in ventilator settings to optimize gas exchange.

2. Meningitis: The patient's CSF analysis shows high protein, low glucose, and turbid fluid, which are indicative of bacterial meningitis. The presence of polymorphonuclear leukocytes (3+ 5-10 per 1000X FIELD) without microorganisms seen on gram stain suggests a bacterial cause. Cryptococcal antigen was not detected, and influenza testing was negative.

The patient's medical complications and potential risks include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a high tidal volume (430 mL), which may lead to further lung injury. The respiratory support needs to be carefully managed to prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

2. Bacterial Meningitis: The patient's cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis suggests bacterial meningitis. The patient is already receiving appropriate antibiotics for this condition.

3. Elevated Intracranial Pressure (ICP): The patient has a high ICP of 25 mmHg, indicating increased pressure within the skull. This can be managed by elevating the head of bed, administering mannitol, and adjusting ventilation parameters to maintain ICP below 20 mmHg.

4. Hypotension: The patient is hypotensive and septic, as indicated by elevated lactate levels. Pressors are being used to maintain adequate blood pressure and cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP).

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 53-year-old morbidly obese female admitted with evidence of meningitis. She has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics including vancomycin, ceftriaxone, ampicillin, and acyclovir. The patient's condition initially showed improvement, but she developed increased intracranial pressure (ICP) requiring mannitol and hypertonic saline. An ICP bolt was placed, and her ICP was successfully reduced. The patient's cardiac markers have peaked, indicating possible cardiac involvement. She is intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient's vital signs are stable, with controlled blood pressure and heart rate. However, she remains critically ill in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cerebral Edema: The patient's increased ICP indicates cerebral edema, which can lead to further neurological deterioration if not managed appropriately.
2. Meningitis: Although the patient is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, the causative organism has not been identified yet. It is important to continue monitoring for any signs of deterioration or complications related to meningitis.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure requires close monitoring and adjustment of ventilator settings to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
4. Cardiac Dysfunction: The patient's cardiac markers have peaked, suggesting possible cardiac involvement. Further evaluation with a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is recommended to assess

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with respiratory failure and cerebral edema, suspected bacterial meningitis. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to altered mental status and instability. She has been receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics (Vancomycin, ceftriaxone, ampicillin, acyclovir) and her ICP has improved after mannitol/hypertonic saline and hyperventilation. An ICP monitor is in place, and an EEG will be done today to evaluate for seizures. Repeat LP is planned for Monday. The patient's respiratory support is going well, with oxygenation and ability to liberalize respiratory rate/high MV given short-lived benefit from hyperventilation and improved ICP.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Presumed bacterial meningitis/cerebral edema: The patient's primary issue is presumed bacterial meningitis with cerebral edema. It is crucial to continue broad-spectrum antibiotics and monitor ICP closely. Steroids may not be indicated at this time. Follow-up cultures and HSV PCR are pending.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated due to respiratory failure. Continuing acv support, oxygenating well, and liberalizing respiratory rate/high MV should be maintained. The patient's altered mental status and instability require close monitoring.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which could be due to multiple potential causes such as mannitol,

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with respiratory failure and cerebral edema in the setting of suspected bacterial meningitis. She is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. The patient has been receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin, ceftriaxone, ampicillin, and acyclovir. Her condition is critical, and she is being closely monitored for potential complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis-myocardial dysfunction: The patient's cardiac markers have peaked, and there is suspicion of sepsis-myocardial dysfunction. Close monitoring of heart function and hemodynamics is essential.
2. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which has been normalized. It is important to maintain sodium levels within the desired range and monitor for any signs of electrolyte imbalance.
3. Transaminitis: The patient shows signs of transaminitis, likely due to shock liver from hypotension. Close monitoring of liver function is necessary.
4. NGMA (Non-Gastrointestinal Motility Abnormalities): The patient has NGMA, possibly related to NS resuscitation. Monitoring of gastrointestinal motility and function is important.
5. Tachycardia: The patient is experiencing tachycardia, likely due to an inflammatory process, fever, insensible losses, and possible intravascular dryness. Monitoring heart rate and fluid status is crucial.

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with respiratory failure and cerebral edema in the setting of suspected bacterial meningitis. The patient remains minimally responsive but is still on sedation. The primary issues include presumed bacterial meningitis, cerebral edema, and altered mental status. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated due to respiratory failure, instability, hypoxemia, and altered mental status. Continuous assisted ventilation support and oxygenation are ongoing.

2. Cerebral edema: The patient has cerebral edema, which is being managed with ICP monitoring, mannitol/hypertonic saline administration, and hyperventilation. EEG evaluation is planned to assess for seizures.

3. Bacterial meningitis: The patient has suspected bacterial meningitis, and broad-spectrum antibiotics (vancomycin, ceftriaxone, ampicillin, acyclovir) are being continued. Cultures and HSV PCR are being followed up.

4. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, and the aim is to maintain sodium levels in the range of 145-150. Free water intake is being decreased to correct this electrolyte imbalance.

5. Transaminitis: The patient has transaminitis, which is likely a component of shock liver from hypotension. Liver function is improving slowly.

6. NGMA (non-gastric mucosal bleeding): The patient

She is currently admitted to the ICU and is being treated for meningitis, respiratory failure, encephalitis, and hypotension. The patient's condition has shown some improvement, but she remains critically ill with ongoing medical complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Meningitis: The patient is already being treated for meningitis with antibiotics. However, there is a risk of treatment failure or recurrence if the causative organism is resistant to the current antibiotics or if the patient develops antibiotic resistance.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. There is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and barotrauma from the positive pressure ventilation.

3. Encephalitis: The patient has encephalitis, which can lead to further neurological deterioration. There is a risk of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) and cerebral edema.

4. Hypotension: The patient had hypotension previously, but it has resolved. There is still a risk of recurrent hypotension, especially if the patient develops septic shock or experiences a cardiac event.

5. Elevated Cardiac Enzymes: The patient has elevated cardiac enzymes, indicating possible cardiac damage. There is a risk of further myocardial injury or heart failure.

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 53-year-old female with hypertension presenting with fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema.
- She has been intubated and sedated, and is currently on mechanical ventilation.
- The patient has been diagnosed with meningitis, as evidenced by leukocytosis and fevers.
- An intraventricular bolt was placed but subsequently removed by neurosurgery.
- The patient's ICP is improving, but she remains unable to assess mental status due to sedation.
- A head CT with contrast did not provide sufficient information to assess for intracranial infection or leptomeningial disease.
- The patient's respiratory status has been unstable, requiring increased sedation and adjustment of ventilator settings.
- She has developed new bilateral pneumonia, which is suspected to be ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
- The patient's sodium levels are being carefully monitored, and hypertonic saline and mannitol are being used to manage her cerebral edema.
- She is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics (Vanc, CTX, ampicillin, acyclovir) and further cultures and tests are pending.
- The patient's blood pressure is well-controlled with the use of pressors.

Potential Medical Complications:

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old female with hypertension who presented with fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. The patient has been diagnosed with several conditions including fever, respiratory failure, encephalitis, hypotension, and elevated cardiac enzymes.

The potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Meningitis: The patient's symptoms of fever and altered mental status could be indicative of meningitis. If left untreated, meningitis can lead to further deterioration in mental status and potentially life-threatening complications.

2. Cerebral edema: The presence of diffuse cerebral edema is concerning as it can increase intracranial pressure (ICP) and potentially cause brain herniation. Monitoring and managing ICP through measures such as elevating the head of bed, dextrose restriction, and use of hypertonic saline may be necessary to prevent further complications.

3. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. Prolonged mechanical ventilation increases the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and barotrauma. Close monitoring of respiratory parameters and weaning trials when appropriate are essential to minimize these risks.

4. Hypotension: The patient has experienced episodes of hypotension, which if not properly managed, can lead to organ hypoperfusion and potential organ damage. Continuous monitoring and appropriate use of vasopressors may be required to maintain adequate blood pressure

   persistent fever: will broaden gram-negative coverage to include
   cefipime and discuss with ID re: meningitis dosing.

   agitation.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of obesity admitted to the ICU for meningitis and respiratory failure. The patient remains on broad-spectrum antibiotics and is awaiting HSV PCR results to determine if acyclovir can be discontinued. 

The patient's respiratory support includes an endotracheal tube, mechanical ventilation in the assist-control mode with a set tidal volume of 430 mL, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, PEEP of 12 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, and spontaneous respiratory rate of 0 breaths per minute. The ABG results indicate a pH of 7.43, PaCO2 of 31 mmHg, PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 383, and Ve of 12.1 L/min.

Physical examination reveals that the patient does not awaken to voice or sternal rub, has equal and round pupils that are reactive, diffuse rhonchi and scattered wheezing in the chest, regular rapid respirations, and minimal edema in the extremities.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 18.6 K/uL, decreased hemoglobin (Hct) of 27.7%, slightly elevated platelet count (Plt) of 75 K/uL, normal creatinine (Cr) of 0.6 mg/dL, and elevated troponin-T level of 1

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension who is currently in the ICU due to fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. The patient has been experiencing episodes of ectopy overnight and has had her potassium and magnesium levels repleted. She was switched to propofol to lighten sedation in order to better assess her mental status. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the presence of fever. 

Vital signs include a temperature of 38.2 degrees Celsius, blood pressure ranging from 131/76 mmHg to 192/111 mmHg, heart rate of 100 bpm, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's head rhythm is sinus tachycardia, and her CVP is within normal limits. 

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin levels, normal glucose levels, and abnormal liver function tests. Imaging shows improved bilateral opacities on chest X-ray. Microbiology results indicate the presence of gram-negative rods in the sputum, but further incubation is required for identification. 

Assessment and plan:
The patient is being treated for fever, respiratory failure, encephalitis, and hypertension. The plan includes weaning off propofol to evaluate mental status, elevating the head of bed, discontinuing hypertonic saline and mannitol, maintaining sodium levels above 140

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension, presenting with fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. She has been diagnosed with meningitis, respiratory failure, encephalitis, and hypertension. The patient's medical history includes recent neurosurgery to remove a bolt, for which she was admitted to the ICU. She is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. Her condition has been complicated by fever, hypotension, and new bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray, indicating pneumonia. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.2C (100.8F), blood pressure ranging from 131/76 mmHg to 192/111 mmHg, heart rate between 94-120 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's neurological status is described as sedated and encephalopathic, with an altered mental status. 

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hematocrit, and platelet count within normal limits. Other lab values, including electrolytes, liver function tests, kidney function tests, and cardiac markers, are within normal ranges or show nonspecific findings. Imaging studies reveal diffuse opacities on chest X-ray and negative findings on head CT with contrast.

The patient's current plan includes continued treatment for meningitis with vancomycin, cefepime, and ampicillin,

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 53-year-old female with a chief complaint of altered mental status and suspected meningitis. The patient is currently in the ICU and has been diagnosed with multiple medical conditions including respiratory failure, meningitis, and possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). 

The patient's vital signs show a fever (Tmax: 38.3C), tachycardia (HR: 112 bpm), hypertension (BP: 146/86 mmHg), tachypnea (RR: 22 breaths/min), and normal oxygen saturation (SpO2: 98%). The patient's neurological status is poor, as she is unresponsive and has a seizure on EEG.

The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count (WBC: 18.6 K/uL), slightly decreased hemoglobin (Hct: 32.3%), normal platelet count (Plt: 180 K/uL), elevated creatinine (Cr: 0.6 mg/dL), elevated troponin T (TropT: 1.00 ng/mL), and normal glucose levels (Glucose: 137 mg/dL). Other lab results show elevated liver enzymes (ALT: 66 U/L, AST: 25 U/L), decreased albumin (Albumin: 2.6 g/dL), and elevated lactate acid (Lactic Acid: 1.3 mmol/L).

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension and obesity, currently in the ICU for suspected bacterial meningitis. She is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode. Her vital signs include a temperature of 38.3C (101F), heart rate of 112 bpm, blood pressure of 146/86 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on FiO2 40%. She has a central venous pressure of 6 mmHg and fluid balance showing an input of 3,307 mL and output of 3,410 mL since 12 AM.

Her laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 18.6 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.2 g/dL, platelet count of 75 K/uL, creatinine of 0.6 mg/dL, and troponin-T of 1.00 ng/mL. Imaging shows improving bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, and microbiology results are pending.

The patient's assessment and plan include ongoing management of her neurologic status, respiratory failure, and meningitis. Neurologic status will be monitored through attempts to awaken the patient off propofol and performing a neuro exam. Respiratory failure barriers to extubation include mental status and obesity, with plans to check ABG today, perform spontaneous breathing trial when sitting upright, aim for diuresis

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension, presenting with fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. She has been diagnosed with meningitis and is currently admitted to the ICU for further management. The patient is on mechanical ventilation, and her respiratory status has been improving. She has been experiencing fevers and seizures, and continuous EEG showed possible seizure activity. The patient's sodium levels need to be maintained above 140, and she is receiving antibiotics for suspected bacterial meningitis. There are concerns about intracranial infection/leptomeningial disease, and a repeat head CT with contrast is needed to assess this. The patient's pneumonia appears to be improving with cefepime therapy, but there may be a need to change back to ceftriaxone. There is also a concern for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient's glycemic control is being managed with regular insulin sliding scale.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Meningitis: The patient is still experiencing fevers and altered mental status, indicating ongoing inflammation of the meninges. If left untreated, meningitis can lead to severe complications such as brain abscesses, hearing loss, vision loss, and even death.
2. Seizures: The patient has been having seizures, which can be a direct result of the meningitis or the underlying cause. Seizures can increase the risk of injury and may require ongoing management with antiepile

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension presenting with fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. She has been diagnosed with meningitis and is currently being treated with vancomycin, cefepime, and ampicillin. The patient's seizures have been controlled with dilantin. She is intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. There are concerns about possible encephalitis and the need for further neurologic evaluation. The patient also has pneumonia, and her sputum culture is growing yeast. She is receiving regular insulin for glycemic control and has multiple lines, including an arterial line. The patient is on prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcers. Her code status is full code.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. Complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or barotrauma should be monitored and managed appropriately.
2. Meningitis: The patient's condition requires close monitoring for any signs of deterioration or worsening of meningitis symptoms. Antibiotics should be continued as prescribed, and regular CSF/blood cultures should be followed.
3. Encephalitis: Given the patient's altered mental status and diffuse cerebral edema, encephalitis needs to be considered. Regular neurologic checks and follow-up with neurology consultants are necessary.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a chief complaint of meningitis. She has been in the ICU for several days and is currently experiencing fevers, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. The patient has been on various antibiotics including acyclovir, cefepime, ceftriaxone, and ampicillin. She is also receiving continuous EEG monitoring due to possible seizure activity.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has been diagnosed with DVT in her left profunda femoral vein. This condition can lead to complications such as pulmonary embolism or further clot propagation.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode and has a low respiratory system compliance. This indicates difficulty in weaning off the ventilator, which may result in prolonged mechanical ventilation or respiratory distress syndrome.

3. Encephalitis: The patient's altered mental status and continuous EEG showing possible seizure activity suggest encephalitis as a potential complication. This condition can progress to coma or permanent neurological damage if not managed appropriately.

4. Hypotension: The patient has episodes of hypotension, which can be caused by sepsis secondary to meningitis or other underlying conditions. Persistent hypotension can lead to organ failure and shock.

5. Pneumonia: The patient has developed bilateral pneumonia, which may be a nosocomial

80. Can

   # Hypertension: Pattern consistent with repiratory issues cause

   blocker withdrawal given htn/tachycardia.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension who was admitted with meningitis. She is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's fever has been low-grade, and there are findings of fluid overload or possible early pneumonia on chest X-ray. There is also an increasing leukocytosis, which may indicate an evolving infection. Other possible etiologies include known DVT and meningitis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is currently stable with oxygen saturation at 94% on FiO2 50%. However, there is mild hypoxemia, likely related to fluid or possible infection. There is a small possibility of hypertensive flash pulmonary edema. The plan includes restarting AC setting on vent, lasix 20 mg IV, and antibiotics.

2. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has been diagnosed with LLE DVT. She is now on heparin drip with approval from Neurosurgery, with the goal of achieving a PTT of 60-80. Considering the patient's weight, she cannot be given Lovenox.

3. Meningitis: The patient's mental status continues to improve, but she is febrile and leukocytosis may be related to a lung source or CNS source. A head CT with contrast is needed to assess for subtle intracranial infection

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. The patient has been in the ICU since [**2109-12-19**] and has been diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), lower extremity fever, acute respiratory failure (not ARDS), and encephalitis.

Over the past 24 hours, the patient's condition has been monitored closely. They experienced tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypertension during a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) attempt and were unable to wean off supplemental oxygen. The patient's sodium level was initially low but normalized after restarting hypertonic saline. A Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremities revealed a positive finding for DVT, for which the patient was started on heparin.

Other notable interventions include the administration of IV lasix to aid with diuresis, restarting home diltiazem, and increasing the dose of dilantin due to low levels. The patient's last doses of antibiotics were acyclovir, cefipime, ceftriaxone, ampicillin, and vancomycin.

3. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure requires close monitoring and management. If not properly treated, it can lead to hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis, resulting in multi-organ dysfunction.
4. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The presence of DVT increases the risk

   # Fever: Low grade temperature this morning. CXR findings consistent
   with fluid overload or possible early pneumonia. Increasing

   etiologies include known DVT, meningitis.

   - restart AC setting on vent

   #  Meningitis: Mental status continues to improve. Febrile and
   leukocoytosis may be related to lung source vs CNS source. Head CT with
   contrast from OSH not sufficient to assess for subtle intracranial
   infection/leptomeningial disease.  Continuous EEG showed possible
   seizure activity and completed today. Dilantin level approaching
   therapeutic with increase dose.

80. Can

   # Hypertension: Pattern consistent with repiratory issues cause
   hypertension, rather than vice versa. Restarted diltiazem yesterday.

   blocker withdrawal given htn/tachycardia.

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension who presented with fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. She was found to have meningitis, which is an infection of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord. The patient also has respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation, and a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her left lower extremity.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's prolonged intubation and mechanical ventilation, there is a risk of developing VAP, a type of lung infection acquired during or after mechanical ventilation.
2. Central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI): With multiple central lines in place, such as the PICC line and multi-lumen line, there is a risk of developing a bloodstream infection.
3. Pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient's DVT increases the risk of a blood clot dislodging and traveling to the lungs, causing a potentially life-threatening PE.
4. Meningitis-related complications: Despite treatment, the patient may experience complications related to meningitis, such as neurological deficits or septic shock.
5. Hypotension: The patient's history of hypertension and current presentation may lead to episodes of low blood pressure, which can compromise organ perfusion.
6. Seizures: The patient's altered mental status and EEG findings suggest an increased risk of seizures, which can be managed with appropriate ant

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with hypertension, who presented with fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. She was diagnosed with meningitis complicated by respiratory failure, possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's condition has been unstable with fluctuating vital signs and ongoing infections.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for developing VAP due to endotracheal intubation and prolonged mechanical ventilation. This can be indicated by increasing leukocytosis, fever, and worsening respiratory status.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient has already been diagnosed with DVT in the left lower extremity. If left untreated, it can lead to pulmonary embolism, which is a life-threatening complication.
3. Meningitis: The patient is suffering from meningitis, which is an infection of the meninges, the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. It can result in severe neurological complications if not appropriately managed.
4. Hypotension: The patient has episodes of hypotension, which can be caused by septic shock or fluid overload. Proper fluid management and hemodynamic support are crucial to maintain adequate blood pressure.
5. Hypoxemia: The patient experiences persistent hypoxemia, indicating impaired oxygenation. This can be due to underlying lung pathology or fluid accumulation.
6. seizures

   53 yo F w/ HTN p/w fever altered mental status and diffuse cerebral
   edema and found to have meningitis complicated by respiratory failure,
   possible VAP and DVT
   # Fever: Febrile yesterday to 102.8 despite broadened antibiotic
   coverage for VAP yesterday. Central line removed and sent for culture,
   and mini bal performed yesterday, however no organisms were seen on GS.
   Leukocytosis stable since yesterday. CXR findings could be consistent
   with early multilobar pneumonia. Increasing leukocytosis also
   concerning for evolving infection.
   - Continue Cefepime for VAP coverage
   - follow up minibal results
   - Appreciate ID input
   - CT head and C spine per ID to evaluate for abscess
   - Continue Vanco/ampillin as noted below. Hold vanco for now pending
   level tomorrow morning
   # Hypoxemia/Respiratory status: Hypoxemic after BAL yesterday, and
   continued hypoxemia on gas this morning. However, sats now improved.
   Likely related to some degree of fluid or possible infection. Did not
   meet I/O goal yesterday. - restart AC setting on vent
   - lasix 40 mg Ivx1 with goal I/o negative 2 L
   - Antibiotics as noted above
   #  Meningitis: Mental status continues to improve. Febrile and
   leukocoytosis may be related to lung source vs CNS source. Head CT with
   contrast from OSH not sufficient to assess for subtle intracranial
   infection/leptomeningial disease.  Continuous EEG showed possible
   seizure activity and completed today. Dilantin level approaching
   therapeutic with increase dose. Change phenytoin to fosphenytoin
   yesterday.
   - HOB elevation
   - Maintain Na>140
   - Vanc/Cefepime/ampicillin
   - follow CSF/blood cultures/sputum cultures
   - f/u Neuro and ID recs
   - neuro checks q2 H
   - Phenytoin changed to fosphenytoin
   # DVT: LLE DVT on LENI [**12-25**]. Possible source of fevers. Now on heparin
   drip with approval from Neurosurgery with goal PTT 60
80. Can not
   consider Lovenox given patient weight.
   # Hypertension: Blood pressure much better controlled over last 24
   hours after starting betablocker. Pattern consistent with repiratory
   issues cause hypertension, rather than vice versa. Restarted diltiazem
   yesterday. Home dose of atenolol 25 mg daily, and she may be having
   some beta blocker withdrawal given htn/tachycardia.
   - Continue metoprolol and diltiazem. Will restart home atenolol once
   more stable.
   - lasix as above

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension, presenting with fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. She was found to have meningitis complicated by respiratory failure, possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). 

The patient's fever is persisting despite broadened antibiotic coverage for VAP, and she remains febrile. The central line has been removed and sent for culture, and a mini-balloon percutaneous aspiration was performed, but no organisms were seen on gram stain. Leukocytosis is stable since yesterday. Chest X-ray findings could be consistent with early multilobar pneumonia. Increasing leukocytosis is also concerning for evolving infection.

In terms of management, the patient will continue on cefepime for VAP coverage, and follow-up mini-bal results are expected. ID input is appreciated, along with a CT head and C spine to evaluate for abscess. Vancomycin and ampicillin will be continued as noted below, with vancomycin held for now pending level tomorrow morning.

The patient's respiratory status has shown improvement in oxygen saturation levels. However, she remains hypoxemic after the mini-BAL procedure yesterday. The restart AC setting on the ventilator, along with lasix 40 mg IV q1 with goal I/O negative 2 L, will be implemented.

Regarding the meningitis, the patient's mental status continues to improve. She

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension, admitted to the ICU for fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. She was diagnosed with meningitis and has developed respiratory failure, possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's condition remains critical, and she requires ongoing intensive care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation increases the risk of developing VAP. Close monitoring of respiratory parameters and appropriate antibiotic therapy is essential to prevent and treat this complication.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient has already been diagnosed with DVT in the lower extremity. It is crucial to continue anticoagulation therapy and consider measures to prevent further clot formation, such as early ambulation and compression stockings.
3. Cerebral edema and increased intracranial pressure (ICP): The patient's diffuse cerebral edema and altered mental status indicate the possibility of increased ICP. Monitoring for signs of neurological deterioration and managing cerebral edema through appropriate interventions, such as head elevation and osmotic therapy, is important.
4. Seizures: The patient had seizure activity detected on continuous EEG, suggesting the possibility of seizures. Prophylactic antiepileptic drugs may be necessary to prevent further seizures.
5. Nosocomial infections: Due to the patient's prolonged hospital stay and invasive

   53 yo F w/ HTN p/w fever altered mental status and diffuse cerebral
   edema and found to have meningitis complicated by respiratory failure,
   possible VAP and DVT
   # Fever: Febrile yesterday to 102.8 despite broadened antibiotic
   coverage for VAP. Respiratory secretions continue to be copious.
   Central line removed and sent for culture, and mini bal performed
   yesterday, however no organisms were seen on GS. Leukocytosis stable
   since yesterday. CXR findings could be consistent with early multilobar
   pneumonia.
   - Continue Cefepime for VAP coverage
   - follow up minibal results
   - Appreciate ID input
   - CT head and C spine per ID to evaluate for abscess
   - Continue Vanco/ampillin as noted below. Hold vanco for now pending
   level tomorrow morning
   # Hypoxemia/Respiratory status: Hypoxemic after BAL yesterday, and
   continued hypoxemia on gas this morning. However, sats now improved.
   Likely related to some degree of fluid or possible infection. Did not
   meet I/O goal yesterday.
   - lasix 20 mg Ivx1 with goal I/o negative 1 L
   - Restart Pressure support ventilation after radiographic studies
   - Antibiotics as noted above
   #  Meningitis: Mental status continues to improve. Febrile and
   leukocoytosis may be related to lung source vs CNS source. Head CT with
   contrast from OSH not sufficient to assess for subtle intracranial
   infection/leptomeningial disease.  Continuous EEG showed possible
   seizure activity and completed today. Dilantin level approaching
   therapeutic with increase dose. Change phenytoin to fosphenytoin
   yesterday.
   - HOB elevation
   - Follow up CT head from today re: change in cerebral edema
   - Touch base with Neurosurg re: importance of maintaining Na>140 with
   hypertonic saline
   - Vanc/Cefepime/ampicillin
   - follow CSF/blood cultures/sputum cultures
   - f/u Neuro and ID recs
   - neuro checks q2 H
   - Phenytoin changed to fosphenytoin and will need to adjust for albumin
   and weight
   # Constipation: Uptitrate bowel regimen and check LFTs. Consider RUQ
   u/s if LFTs abnormal.
   # DVT: LLE DVT on LENI [**12-25**]. Now on heparin drip with approval from
   Neurosurgery with goal PTT 60
80. Start low dose coumadin given patient
   on several antibiotics.
   - Coumadin 5 mg daily
   - Continue heparin drip
   # Hypertension: Blood pressure much better controlled over last 24
   hours after starting betablocker. Pattern consistent with repiratory
   issues cause hypertension, rather than vice versa. Restarted diltiazem
   yesterday. Home dose of atenolol 25 mg daily, and she may be having
   some beta blocker withdrawal given htn/tachycardia.
   - Continue metoprolol and diltiazem. Will restart home atenolol once
   more stable.
   - lasix as above
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: TFs
   Glycemic Control:  RISS

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension who was admitted to the ICU with fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. She was found to have meningitis complicated by respiratory failure, possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's fever persists despite broadened antibiotic coverage for VAP. She remains hypoxemic and requires pressure support ventilation. Her mental status is improving, but she continues to be febrile and leukocytosis may be related to a lung source or central nervous system (CNS) source. The patient has a history of constipation, hypertension, and DVT. She is currently on multiple antibiotics and anticoagulant therapy. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's respiratory secretions are copious, and she has not met the I/O goal yesterday. This increases the risk of developing VAP. Continuing Cefepime for VAP coverage and following up mini-bal results are recommended.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient has been diagnosed with a lower extremity DVT. She is on heparin drip and will start low-dose coumadin. Regular monitoring of PTT levels is necessary to ensure appropriate anticoagulation.
3. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is better controlled after starting a beta-blocker. Restarting

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 53-year-old female with a chief complaint of meningitis. She has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on multiple medications including cefepime, vancomycin, and ampicillin for suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and meningitis coverage. The patient's vital signs show a fever of 102.8F, tachycardia, hypotension, and respiratory distress.

The patient's arterial line was stopped on 12/26/2109 at 11:08 AM and a multi-lumen line was started on 12/27/2109 at 01:16 AM. She has been receiving midazolam, fentanyl, and heparin infusions. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the presence of fever.

The patient has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her lower extremity, hypertension, and respiratory failure. The assessment and plan include broadening the CTX to cefepime for VAP coverage, performing a mini BAL for sputum gram stain and culture, appreciating ID input, obtaining a CT head and C spine to evaluate for abscess, continuing vancomycin and ampicillin as noted, restarting AC settings on the vent, administering lasix to achieve I/O negative 2 L, and providing antibiotics as mentioned above.

The patient's lab results show leukocytosis,

The patient's vital signs indicate a temperature of 102.8F, blood pressure ranging from 93/57 mmHg to 159/97 mmHg, heart rate between 87-119 bpm, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 93%. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume set at 550 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 33 cmH2O, plateau pressure of 27 cmH2O, and fractional inspired oxygen (FiO2) at 50%.

The patient has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), acute respiratory failure, encephalitis, and hypotension. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal range.

   53 yo F w/ HTN p/w fever altered mental status and diffuse cerebral
   edema and found to have meningitis complicated by respiratory failure
   and DVT
   # Fever: Low grade temperature this morning. CXR findings consistent
   with fluid overload or possible early pneumonia. Increasing
   leukocytosis also concerning for evolving infection. Other possible
   etiologies include known DVT, meningitis.
   - Will broaden CTX to cefepime for VAP coverage
   - Mini bal for sputum gram stain and culture
   - Appreciate ID input
   - CT head and C spine per ID to evaluate for abscess
   - Continue Vanco/ampillin as noted below
   # Hypoxemia/Respiratory status: Mild hypoxemia this morning on Fi02
   50%. Likely related to some degree of fluid or possible infection.
   Small possibility of hypertenive flash pulmonary edema (see below)
   - restart AC setting on vent
   - lasix 20 mg Ivx1 with goal I/o negative 2 L
   - Antibiotics as noted above
   - Htn ad discussed below
   #  Meningitis: Mental status continues to improve. Febrile and
   leukocoytosis may be related to lung source vs CNS source. Head CT with
   contrast from OSH not sufficient to assess for subtle intracranial
   infection/leptomeningial disease.  Continuous EEG showed possible
   seizure activity and completed today. Dilantin level approaching
   therapeutic with increase dose.
   - HOB elevation
   - Maintain Na>140
   - Vanc/Cefepime/ampicillin
   - follow CSF/blood cultures/sputum cultures
   - f/u Neuro and ID recs
   - neuro checks q2 H
   - Con
t dilantin per neuro recs
   # DVT: LLE DVT on LENI yesterday. Possible source of fevers. Now on
   heparin drip with approval from Neurosurgery with goal PTT 60
80. Can
   not consider Lovenox given patient weight.
   # Hypertension: Pattern consistent with repiratory issues cause
   hypertension, rather than vice versa. Restarted diltiazem yesterday.
   Home dose of atenolol 25 mg daily, and she may be having some beta
   blocker withdrawal given htn/tachycardia.
   - Start metoprolol 25 [**Hospital1 **] for shorter acting beta blocker coverage
   - Consider increase diltiazem if tolerated
   - lasix as above

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a chief complaint of meningitis. She has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient has a history of hypertension and was found to have deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her lower extremity. She is febrile with a temperature of 102.8F and leukocytosis, indicating a possible evolving infection. The patient's mental status is improving, but she still has fevers and leukocytosis, which may be related to a lung source or central nervous system (CNS) source. She is on multiple antibiotics for meningitis coverage, including vancomycin, cefepime, and ampicillin. Her blood cultures, sputum cultures, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cultures have been collected. The patient's DVT has been treated with heparin. Her blood pressure is being managed with diltiazem and metoprolol. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation, there is a risk of developing VAP. Measures are in place to prevent this, such as head-of-bed elevation, daily wake-up trials, and mouth care.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 102.8 degrees Fahrenheit, heart rate of 92 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 102/65 mmHg to 159/97 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient is intubated and sedated, but able to follow commands.

The patient's lab results show an elevated white blood cell count, slightly decreased hemoglobin level, elevated creatinine level, and abnormal liver function tests. The patient's blood cultures have been negative so far, but a mini-balloon (BAL) showed no growth of microorganisms.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 53-year-old morbidly obese female with meningitis, respiratory failure, and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). She was admitted with obtundation and found to have meningitis. The patient has been on mechanical ventilation and is currently intubated. She has been receiving antibiotics for meningitis, including vancomycin, ampicillin, and cefipime. Her mental status has been improving, and she is now able to follow commands. She also has been experiencing fevers, seizures, and respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Meningitis: The patient has been diagnosed with meningitis, and it is important to continue the appropriate antibiotic therapy. There is a risk of complications such as brain abscess, hearing loss, or cognitive impairment if the infection is not adequately treated.

2. Seizures: The patient had an EEG positive for seizures yesterday, and she is currently on dilantin for seizure prophylaxis. Continuous EEG monitoring will be continued, and the plan is to wean versed later today. There is a risk of recurrent seizures if the antiseizure medication is not properly managed.

3. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated due to respiratory failure, primarily due to hypoxemia and airway protection. The primary barrier to extubation is her mental status, which is improving, and her persistent high positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP).

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 53-year-old lady with morbid obesity admitted to the ICU for meningitis, respiratory failure, and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient is currently sedated and intubated due to respiratory failure. She has been diagnosed with meningitis but no pathogen has been identified yet. The patient's condition has been complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), persistent fevers, and DVT.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 102.8F (39.3C), heart rate of 92 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 102/65 mmHg to 159/97 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is 3 mmHg, and fluid balance shows an intake of 3,239 mL and output of 3,410 mL.

The patient has received various medications, including vancomycin, ampicillin, cefepime, midazolam (versed), fentanyl, heparin sodium, dilantin, fosphenytoin, famotidine (pepcid), and metoprolol. 

Laboratory results indicate leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 291 K/uL and elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) levels. Blood cultures have been negative so far. Imaging

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old lady with morbid obesity who was admitted with obtundation and found to have meningitis. The patient's course has been complicated by respiratory failure, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and fever.

The patient underwent a mini-balloon percutaneous dilatational tracheostomy (mini-BAL) and had transient hypoxemia, which then resolved. She also developed a fever to 102.8 yesterday evening. A new subclavian central venous catheter (SC CVC) was placed in the right internal jugular vein (IJ).

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 38.6C (101.4F), heart rate of 92 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 102/65 to 93/56 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95% on endotracheal tube ventilation. The patient's rhythm is sinus rhythm.

The patient's physical examination reveals that she is intubated and sedated, with supple neck and no palpable right IJ hematoma. Chest X-ray shows the distal end of the left subclavian catheter projecting over the distal brachiocephalic vein and no evidence of complications. The cardiac silhouette remains unchanged, and there is still retrocardiac opacity suggesting atelectasis.

The patient is a 53-year-old morbidly obese lady admitted with obtundation and diagnosed with meningitis. She has experienced respiratory failure, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and fever. The patient is intubated and sedated, and her mental status is improving slowly. She has been treated with antibiotics, antiepileptic medication, and anticoagulants. Several tests have been performed, including blood cultures, respiratory cultures, and imaging studies. The patient continues to have persistent fevers and is being treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Meningitis: The patient initially showed improvement in white blood cell count, but it increased again. She has persistent fevers, and no pathogen has been identified yet. There is a need to recheck trough levels of vancomycin and consider alternative treatment options if necessary.
2. Seizures: The patient's EEG is positive, indicating seizure activity. Her mental status is improving with the use of dilantin, but she has been switched to fosphenytoin for central administration. It is important to continue monitoring her seizure activity and adjust dilantin levels based on albumin levels.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated due to hypoxemia and airway protection. Her primary barrier to extubation is her improving mental status. She is being treated for VAP, and her secretions

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- Patient is a 53-year-old lady with morbid obesity, admitted with obtundation and diagnosed with meningitis.
- The patient's course has been complicated by respiratory failure and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
- The patient is currently intubated due to hypoxemia and airway protection.
- She is receiving multiple antibiotics for meningitis, including vancomycin, ampicillin, and cefipime.
- Dilantin has been started for seizures, and the patient's mental status is improving.
- The patient has persistent fevers, and all cultures have been negative.
- She is on heparin for DVT and has a central venous catheter changed yesterday.
- The plan is to wean PEEP and FiO2 as tolerated, attempt spontaneous breathing trials (SBT), and continue to allow auto-diuresis with Lasix as needed.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Meningitis: The patient is still febrile, and no pathogen has been identified yet. There is a risk of worsening meningitis or development of complications such as brain edema or increased intracranial pressure.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is dependent on mechanical ventilation and may face challenges during weaning due to persistent high PEEP and mental status impairment.
3. Seizures: The patient had an EEG positive for seizures yesterday, and there is a risk of recurrent seizures despite being on dilant

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old lady with morbid obesity, who was admitted with obtundation and found to have meningitis. The patient's course has been complicated by respiratory failure and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient underwent mini-balloon percutaneous aspiration of lung (mini-BAL) due to transient hypoxemia, which then resolved. Fever to 102.8 was noted yesterday evening. A new large-bore central venous catheter (L SC line) was placed in the right internal jugular vein (RIJ). A CT scan of the head and spine was performed this morning.

The patient has a history of obesity, and her allergies include no known drug allergies. She has received multiple doses of antibiotics since admission, including ceftriaxone, cefepime, ampicillin, and vancomycin. The patient is currently receiving midazolam (versed), fentanyl, heparin sodium, dilantin, furosemide (Lasix), famotidine (Pepcid), and fosphenytoin.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.6C (101.4F), heart rate of 92 bpm (87-119 bpm), blood pressure of 102/65 mmHg (73/64-159/112 mmHg), respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute (9-29 breaths per minute), and oxygen saturation of

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

- The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension who presented with fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. She was found to have meningitis, complicated by respiratory failure, possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
- The patient's fever has subsided after removing the right internal jugular (RIJ) central line and broadening antibiotics to cefepime. CT scans show no extra focus of infection.
- The patient's respiratory status is improving, with improved oxygen saturation (sats). However, she remains hypoxemic and may have fluid overload or infection contributing to this.
- The patient's mental status continues to improve, indicating a positive response to treatment.
- The patient has leukocytosis, which could be related to a lung source or central nervous system (CNS) source. Continuous electroencephalogram (EEG) showed possible seizure activity.
- The patient's blood pressure is better controlled with the use of beta-blockers.
- The patient has constipation, which is being treated with an uptitration of the bowel regimen.
- The patient has a lower extremity DVT and is on heparin drip with approval from neurosurgery. She has started low-dose Coumadin due to being on several antibiotics.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension who presented with fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. She was found to have meningitis complicated by respiratory failure, possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

The patient's current condition:
1. Fever: The patient is now relatively afebrile for 24 hours after pulling the right internal jugular (RIJ) central line and broadening antibiotics to cefepime. A fever can indicate an infection or inflammation in the body.
2. Respiratory status: The patient's oxygen saturation improved after a bronchoscopy and lavage (BAL) procedure. However, she remains hypoxemic and may be related to fluid overload or infection. The goal is to achieve adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
3. Meningitis: The patient's mental status continues to improve, indicating a positive response to treatment. She is still febrile and leukocytosis may be related to a lung source or central nervous system (CNS) source. Further evaluation with head CT and continuous electroencephalogram (EEG) is planned to assess for possible seizures.
4. DVT: The patient has a left lower extremity DVT and is currently on heparin drip with approval from neurosurgery. The target PTT (partial thromboplastin time) is 60-80 seconds.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old lady with morbid obesity who was admitted with obtundation and found to have meningitis. The course of treatment has been complicated by respiratory failure and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). 

The patient's current vital signs show a temperature of 37.6C (99.7F), heart rate of 102 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 106/62 mmHg to 141/91 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. 

The patient is receiving multiple medications including antibiotics (vancomycin, ampicillin, cefipime), anticoagulant (heparin), sedatives (midazolam, fentanyl), and antiepileptic (fosphenytoin). 

The lab results indicate elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, elevated platelet count, slightly elevated creatinine, and normal glucose levels. Other lab values are within normal ranges or not significantly abnormal.

Assessment and plan:
1. Meningitis: The patient's WBC count improved initially but increased again, indicating persistent infection. The patient has persistent fevers and mental status improvement. She is currently on vancomycin, ampicillin, and cefipime. Vancomycin will be held until tomorrow and the trough will be rechecked.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old morbidly obese female admitted with meningitis, respiratory failure, and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's condition is summarized as follows:

- The patient's mental status is improving slowly, and she is now able to follow commands.
- She has persistent fevers, and her white blood cell count has initially improved but then increased again.
- No abscess was seen on the head/spine CT from yesterday.
- The patient is currently on vancomycin, ampicillin, and cefipime for a total of two weeks for meningitis treatment.
- The patient is also being treated for seizures with phenytoin.
- The patient is intubated due to respiratory failure and is being treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
- Secretions are copious, and there is a concern for increasing atelectasis, particularly in the left lower lobe.
- The patient's PEEP is being weaned today.
- The patient has resolved fevers, and all cultures are negative to date.
- She has a diagnosed DVT and is receiving heparin and coumadin.
- The patient has hypertension, which is being managed with beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers.
- She experiences diffuse abdominal pain, which is thought to be related to her bowel regimen and may require further investigation.
- The patient has anemia, with a hematocrit drop yesterday,

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old morbidly obese female admitted with obtundation and diagnosed with meningitis. The patient's course has been complicated by respiratory failure and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's mental status has been improving slowly, and they are now able to follow commands. The patient is intubated due to hypoxemia and airway protection, and primary barriers to extubation include mental status and copious secretions. The patient is being treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient's fevers persist despite negative cultures, and they have been placed on heparin for DVT. The patient's blood pressure is difficult to control, and they have a history of hypertension. The patient also experiences diffuse abdominal pain and has not had a bowel movement since admission. The patient is receiving various medications for their condition, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and medications for seizures and blood pressure management.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Meningitis: The patient has been diagnosed with meningitis, which is an infection of the meninges, the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. Complications of meningitis can include brain abscess, hearing loss, and long-term neurological deficits.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing respiratory failure, which may lead to further complications such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and decreased oxygenation.
3. Deep Vein Thrombosis

   5. Large right thyroid nodule; non-urgent ultrasound recommended.
   6. Cholelithiasis.
   Assessment and Plan
   53F with meningitis but no pathogen identified, course c/b VAP,
   persistent fevers, and DVT.
   1.  Meningitis:  WBC improved initially, then back up yesterday,
   trending down again today. Has persistent fevers, mental status
   improving and now able to follow commands.  No abscess on head/spine CT
   from yesterday.
   - currently on vancomycin (changing to 1250 Q8 per ID), ampicillin,
   cefipime x 2 weeks total course per ID
   - no steroids per d/w ID
   2.  Seizures:  EEG positive, mental status improving with dilantin,
   changed to phosphenytoin for central administration.
   - change back to dilantin as trying to minimize IV meds with access
   problems
   - no more [**Name (NI) **] goals per NSG (s/p hypertonic saline)
   3.  Respiratory Failure:  Intubated in setting of hypoxemia and airway
   protection.  Primary barrier to extubation was her mental status, which
   is improving slowly.  Now treating for VAP.  Secretions copious, and
   increasing today.   Chest CT with bilateral atel vs. consolidation, esp
   in LLL.  Stable on PS, but with high PEEP.
   - wean PEEP today
   - lasix 20 IV x 1 again this am  TBB goal neg 1 L
   4.  Fevers:  now resolved, low grade T max of 100.3  All cultures
   negative to date, LENIs + DVT, on heparin now. Line changed  [**11-26**] (new
   L SC CVC).
   - f/up final cultures (blood, mini BAL)
   5. DVT: heparin gtt, no lovenox given body habitus.  No major
   procedures anticipated in next few days.  Started coumadin yesterday.
   - continue heparin gtt + coumadin
   - check INR today
   6. HTN: restarted BBL at low dose, on home dose of diltiazem
   7. Abdominal pain: diffuse mild TTP, nods to ? re
 abd pain
, had a BM
   yesterday.  Transaminases normal, alk phos stable.
   - check [**Doctor First Name **]/lipase
   - continue bowel regimen
   - KUB today
   8. Anemia: 3 pt hematocrit drop yest, stable today, c/o diffuse abd
   pain
   - stool guaiac
   - consider adding PPI to H2 blocker

The physical examination reveals well-nourished appearance, distant heart sounds, symmetric chest expansion, diminished breath sounds, soft abdomen with tenderness in the right upper quadrant, and edema in both lower extremities. Neurological examination shows attentive behavior, purposeful movements, and normal muscle tone.

Laboratory results indicate leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 12.8 thousand/mm3, decreased hemoglobin level of 7.8 g/dL, elevated platelet count of 415 thousand/mm3, increased creatinine level of 0.4 mg/dL, and elevated troponin-T level of 1.00 ng/mL. Imaging shows right lower lobe infiltrate and atelectasis versus pneumonia, and left lower lobe opacity worsened.

   53 yo F w/ HTN p/w fever altered mental status and diffuse cerebral
   edema and found to have meningitis complicated by respiratory failure,
   possible VAP and DVT
   # Hypoxemia/Respiratory status: Hypoxemic after BAL. However, sats now
   improved.  Likely related to some degree of fluid or possible
   infection.
   - lasix 20 mg Ivx1 with goal I/o negative 1 L
   - PS ventilation, wean PEEP as tolerated, goal <10 today
   - Antibiotics as noted below
   - SBT with possible extubation to CPAP
   # Fever:  Now relatively afebrile x 24 hours after pulling RIJ central
   line and broadening antibiotics to cefepime. CT Head/spine without
   extra focus of infection. CT chest showing PNA.  Could be related to
   new pancreatitis.
   - Continue Cefepime for VAP coverage (8 day course)
   - follow up minibal results
   - hold vanc dose, check trough tonight
   - Appreciate ID input
   - Continue Vanco/ampillin as noted below
   # Abd.pain/pancreatitis:  Improving after holding TF yesterday. Only
   possible drug cause is lasix.
   -NPO
   -Pain control with fentanyl
   -trend lipase
   #  Meningitis: Mental status continues to improve. Febrile and
   leukocoytosis may be related to lung source vs CNS source. Head CT with
   contrast from OSH not sufficient to assess for subtle intracranial
   infection/leptomeningial disease.  Continuous EEG showed possible
   seizure activity and completed today. Dilantin level approaching
   therapeutic with increase dose. Changed phenytoin to fosphenytoin. CT
   head showed slight improvement in edema
   - HOB elevation
   - no need for further hypertonic to keep Na >140
   - Vanc/Cefepime/ampicillin x 2 weeks total
   - follow CSF/blood cultures/sputum cultures
   - f/u Neuro and ID recs
   - neuro checks q2 H
   - Change fosphenytoin to PO dilantin
   # Constipation: Uptitrated bowel regimen
   # DVT: LLE DVT on LENI [**12-25**]. Was on heparin drip with approval from
   Neurosurgery with goal PTT 60
80. Started low dose coumadin given
   patient on several antibiotics.
   - Coumadin 5 mg daily
   # Hypertension: Blood pressure much better controlled over last 24
   hours after starting betablocker. Pattern consistent with repiratory
   issues cause hypertension, rather than vice versa. Restarted diltiazem
   yesterday. Home dose of atenolol 25 mg daily, and she may be having
   some beta blocker withdrawal given htn/tachycardia.
   - Continue metoprolol and diltiazem. Will restart home atenolol once
   more stable.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a chief complaint of meningitis. She has been experiencing fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. The patient is also complicated by respiratory failure, possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

24-hour events include continued right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain with rising lipase levels. The patient has heavy secretions and is still receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics. She was attempted to be weaned off positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) to 8 but did not tolerate it, so she was put back on PEEP 10. The patient has been gagging on the endotracheal tube, and sedation has been increased. The patient may not be able to be extubated today.

Allergies: No known drug allergies.

Last dose of antibiotics:
- Vancomycin: December 30, 2109, at 01:00 AM
- Ampicillin: December 30, 2109, at 04:30 AM
- Cefepime: December 30, 2109, at 05:15 AM

Infusions:
- Midazolam (Versed): 4 mg/hour
- Fentanyl: 200 mcg/hour

Other ICU medications:
- Famotidine (Pepcid): December 29, 2109, at 08

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension who presented with fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. She was found to have meningitis complicated by respiratory failure, possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Summary of Progress:
- The patient's fever has subsided after removing the right internal jugular (RIJ) central line and broadening antibiotics to cefepime.
- A CT scan of the head/spine showed no new focus of infection.
- The CT chest revealed pneumonia, which could be related to new pancreatitis.
- The patient's respiratory status improved with PS ventilation and weaning of PEEP.
- Her mental status continues to improve.
- The abdominal pain and worsening pancreatitis persisted despite holding total parenteral nutrition (TF) yesterday.
- The patient is still febrile and leukocytosis may be related to a lung source or central nervous system (CNS) source.
- Continuous EEG showed possible seizure activity and completed today.
- Dilantin level approached therapeutic with increased dose.
- Phenytoin was changed to fosphenytoin.
- CT head showed slight improvement in edema.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, possibly related to meningitis and VAP. Continuous monitoring and adjustment of ventilation settings are necessary.
2. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient

80. Started low dose coumadin given

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension, who presented with fever, altered mental status, and diffuse cerebral edema. She was found to have meningitis, respiratory failure, possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

24-hour events:
- The patient continued to experience right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain and an increasing lipase level.
- She had heavy secretions, so a sputum culture was sent.
- The patient did not tolerate a decrease in positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) to 8 cmH2O and was returned to 10 cmH2O.
- The patient gagged on the endotracheal tube, leading to an increase in sedation. Extubation may not be possible this morning.

Assessment and Plan:
The patient's fever has subsided after removing the radial internal jugular (RIJ) central line and broadening antibiotics to cefepime. A CT scan of the head/spine without any new focus of infection was performed, along with a CT chest showing possible pneumonia, which could be related to new pancreatitis.
- Continue cefepime for VAP coverage.
- Follow up mini-bal results.
- Recheck sputum culture today due to increased secretions.
- Increase the dose of vancomycin given the low level today.
- Appreciate infectious disease (ID) input.
- Continue vancomycin/ampicillin as noted below.

The patient's hypoxemia and respiratory status improved after a bronchoscopy and alveolar lavage (BAL). The patient's oxygen saturation (sats) is now improved. The hypoxemia is likely related to some degree of fluid or possible infection. The patient did not meet the intake/output (I/O) goal yesterday.
- Lasix 20 mg IV q1 with a goal I/O negative 1 L.
- Pressure-controlled ventilation (PCV), wean PEEP as tolerated, goal <10 today.
- Antibiotics as noted above.

The patient's abdominal pain/pancreatitis worsened despite holding the tube feeds (TF) yesterday. The only possible drug cause is Lasix.
- NPO (nothing by mouth).
- Pain control with fentanyl.
- Check triglycerides.
- RUQ ultrasound (US).

The patient's mental status continues to improve. Fever and leukocytosis may be related to a lung source or central nervous system (CNS) source. A head CT with contrast from outside the hospital (OSH) was not sufficient to assess for subtle intracranial infection/leptomeningeal disease. Continuous EEG showed possible seizure activity and was completed today. The dilantin level is approaching therapeutic with an increased dose. Phenytoin was changed to fosphenytoin. A CT scan of the head showed slight improvement in edema.
- Head of

Summary of the progress note:
The patient is a 53-year-old woman with a history of morbid obesity who underwent gastric bypass surgery. She was admitted to the ICU with meningitis and cerebral edema, requiring intracranial pressure monitoring and status epilepticus. The patient's chief complaint is vague right upper quadrant pain, with elevated amylase and lipase levels. She also experienced subjective dyspnea when weaned to PEEP 8, so her PEEP was increased back to 10. The patient became agitated overnight with increased cough and required increased sedation.

The patient has no known drug allergies. She received vancomycin, ampicillin, and cefepime on December 30th at different times. Her current infusions include midazolam and fentanyl. She was also on furosemide (Lasix) on December 29th and received fentanyl at a different time.

Review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the mentioned symptoms. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.9C (100.3F), heart rate of 93 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 129/47 mmHg to 149/78 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%.
